) Added references throughout this IRM, as appropriate, to the Disclosure Manager Expectations document which is found on the Disclosure Share Point site and provides additional guidance to Disclosure Managers on their supervisory responsibilities. (
) Editorial changes have been made throughout to remove all references to HQ Disclosure and it with HQ Disclosure Policy and Program Operations (PPO). (
) Editorial changes have been made throughout to remove all references to Deputy Associate HQ and replace it with HQ Disclosure Manager. (

Added references throughout this IRM, as appropriate, to the Disclosure Manager Expectations document which is found on the Disclosure Share Point site and provides additional guidance to Disclosure Managers on their supervisory responsibilities.

Title of IRM 11.3.38.3.1 has been changed to Disclosure Awareness and Outreach to provide guidance on both of these Disclosure programs. Other references to Disclosure Awareness have also been updated to include Outreach, where appropriate.
Added Note to IRM 11.3.38.3.1(3) to include information on the “Book a Disclosure Presentation” button which allows IRS business units to easily request a Disclosure awareness presentation.

Title of IRM 11.3.38.3.2 has been changed to Quality Reviews to remove references to Privacy reviews since Disclosure Managers are no longer responsible for completing these reviews. References to Privacy reviews have also been removed from this section and throughout this IRM,
to IRM 1.15, Records and Information Management, was added to the Note in as a resource for records management requirements.

Added new bullet to 11.3.38.3.2(6) to incorporate IRC §6103(d) disclosures to State tax agencies, added Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration to the Government Accountability Office bullet, also removed last 2 bullets in this section.
Removed information in parenthesis in IRM 11.3.38.3.4(2)a since Disclosure Managers do not provide the training to new functional coordinators.
Title of IRM 11.3.38.4 has been changed to Disclosure Coordination with Governmental Liaison and Safeguards Programs.

Added new (2) to IRM 11.3.38.4 to reference the GLDS Roles and Responsibilities Matrix, found on the Disclosure Share Point site, as a resource for coordination with Governmental Liaison and Safeguards.
list in IRM 11.3.38.4.1(3) to better reﬂect the coordination responsibilities of matched these to the items in the GLDS Roles and Responsibilities Matrix.
Removed ﬁrst sentence in IRM 11.3.38.4.1(5). Added Note to IRM 11.3.38.4.1(6)c to provide a resource on the Disclosure Share Point site for the Secure Data Transfer program.

Title of IRM 11.3.38.5 has been changed to Reporting Suspected Willful Unauthorized Accesses or Disclosures. Information from (1) was separated out into new (1) and (2). Other paragraphs in this section were renumbered accordingly. Provided link in new (1) to the TIGTA offices where can report the unauthorized disclosure. Information in new (2) and (3) of this section was updated to conform to reporting procedures on the Privacy and Disclosure Virtual Library. New (5) also added provide guidance on IRC §6103(e)(11) unauthorized disclosure investigations.

Title of IRM 11.3.38.5.1 has been changed to Reporting Non-willful Inadvertent Disclosures. Deleted (2) of this section, all other paragraphs renumbered accordingly. Information in new (2) was updated to conform to reporting procedures on the Privacy and Disclosure Virtual Library, (3) through (6) were deleted and (7) was renumbered to new (3). Reference to Publication 1075 was added in new (3) as a resource for non-IRS agencies to comply with IRS procedures for reporting inadvertent disclosures.

New (3) added to IRM 11.3.38.7 to reference the Disclosure Manager Expectations document which is found on the Disclosure Share Point site and provides additional guidance to Disclosure Managers on their supervisory responsibilities. Subsequent paragraph was renumbered accordingly.
Title of IRM 11.3.38.8 was changed to Electronic Inventory Control System.

New (5) added to IRM 11.3.38.9 to indicate the Senior Disclosure Specialist may have additional duties based on their position descriptions. New (6) also added to show the change in job series of the Disclosure Specialist and Senior Disclosure Specialist to Government Information Specialist.

New IRM section 11.3.38.11 titled The Role of the Tax Law Specialist was added to capture the duties of Tax Law Specialists based on their position descriptions. Information added to this section to show the change in job series of the Tax Law Specialist to Government Information Specialist.

of Disclosure Managers
) Purpose: This section provides guidelines to assist Disclosure Managers in administering an effective and balanced Disclosure program. (
) Audience: These procedures apply to all Disclosure Managers. (
) Policy Owner: The Disclosure office, under Governmental Liaison, and Safeguards (GLDS) is responsible for oversight of Disclosure policy. (
) Program Owner: The GLDS office, under Privacy, Governmental Liaison Disclosure (PGLD) is the program office responsible for oversight of the vicewide Disclosure policy. (

) The conﬁdence the public has in the ability of the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) to protect the conﬁdentiality of tax information inﬂuences the public’s ingness to opt into our voluntary tax system. (

) The Taxpayer Bill of Rights states that taxpayers have the right to expect that any information they provide to the IRS will not be disclosed authorized by the taxpayer or by law. Internal Revenue Code (IRC) provides the guidance for disclosure of taxpayer information, and the rule is returns and return information shall be conﬁdential. The Freedom of formation Act (FOIA) set a standard of “openness in government” that established a withholding decision based on whether the agency foresees that disclosure would harm the agency or its interests. (
) The privacy of employee information is also important and employee tion must only be released in accordance with the Privacy Act or other applicable laws. (

) Disclosure Managers are responsible for implementing activities that privacy principles and/or improve the efficiency of tax administration management) and provide for timely and accurate responses to requests information (casework). (
) The following items govern the authority pertaining to Disclosure Programs Disclosure casework: • IRC §
• Freedom of Information Act (FOIA)
USC §
• Privacy Act
USC §

(1) The Disclosure Manager (DM) serves as the ﬁrst line manager over a staff of employees who provide disclosure services to IRS employees and other stake-
The DM reports directly to the Deputy Associate Director (Deputy AD).
11.3 Disclosure of Official Information
) The Deputy AD is responsible for evaluating and reviewing the DM’s ment of the Disclosure program. (

) Deputy ADs report to the Associate Director, Disclosure, who reports to Director, Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards (GLDS). The Director GLDS reports to the Chief, Privacy Officer, Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure (PGLD). (
) Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure is a service-wide that was organized in June
and includes the former Privacy, Protection and Data Security (PIPDS) functions as well as the GLD and guards programs. (
) The Privacy and Disclosure Virtual Library provides a listing of PGLD and their responsibilities in the “About PGLD” link. See related resources IRM

) The primary objectives of Disclosure offices are as follows: a. Promoting the protection and conﬁdentiality of tax information while ensuring the policy of openness and transparency is considered; b. Preserving the privacy rights of taxpayers and employees; c. Releasing all requested tax and other sensitive information as d. Implementing programs to ensure that IRS employees are fully aware their disclosure responsibilities; and e. Responding to requests for access to tax or other sensitive from various sources. (
) Program Effectiveness: Disclosure Managers participate in ongoing tional Reviews to determine the effectiveness of the disclosure programs implement changes identiﬁed. (

) The following table provides a list of the acronyms that are used in this section: Acronym Deﬁnition Deputy AD Deputy Associate Director DM Disclosure Manager FOIA Freedom of Information Act FTI Federal Tax Information GAO Government Accountability Office GL Governmental Liaison GLDS Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards HQ Headquarters MOU Memorandum of Understanding Internal Revenue Manual Cat. ) Additional information may also be found at these related resources: • FOIA Public Liaison and Disclosure Points of Contact on irs.gov • Privacy and Disclosure Virtual Library • IRS Freedom of Information page on irs.gov • Freedom of Information Act Electronic Reading Room (

) The Disclosure program is divided into two categories: • Case management • Program management Note: The case management responsibilities for caseworkers are described throughout various sections in IRM
This IRM section will describe speciﬁc program management and other management responsibilities and the actions necessary to carry out these responsibilities. (
) Guidelines for the Disclosure program are often provided by the Deputy Associate Directors (Deputy ADs). (
) The Disclosure Manager (DM) is responsible for planning and maintaining a balanced program consistent with operational priorities. (
) Despite the size of the case management workload, program management sponsibilities are equally important and must be met. Efficient and use of resources is the key in meeting this objective. (
) Disclosure office staff serves as the technical experts in all matters. Staff’s ability to provide accurate and timely guidance is a key element of an effective program. (
) Disclosure Managers are responsible for the following: a. Supervisory duties as described in IRM
and the Disclosure Manager Expectations document. b. Coordinating and integrating the Disclosure program with internal and external stakeholders. (

) An effective disclosure program requires the balancing of resources and ties directed towards delivery of both case and program management objectives. A DM must be technically and administratively competent to plish both objectives. (

) Most disclosures made by employees in any given IRS office are made by viduals other than Disclosure personnel. Through program management delivery, the DM imparts the knowledge necessary for IRS management and front-line personnel to make correct disclosure decisions. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
Q
of Disclosure Managers
) The DM serves as liaison in disclosure matters with other governmental agencies. (

) The DM supports the Governmental Liaison (GL) by reviewing negotiated agreements to ensure appropriate provisions are included where the of federal tax information (FTI), personally identiﬁable information (PII) or sensitive but unclassiﬁed (SBU) information is involved. (

) There are many aspects of the work that are also affected by privacy and initiatives promulgated by the Office of Privacy, Governmental Liaison Disclosure (PGLD). The DM, because of his/her expertise, may be called on assist or advise in matters that impact privacy policy for ﬁeld operations or be asked to provide resources in support of various PGLD programs or projects. (

) Disclosure is responsible for several programs that have a Servicewide • Awareness and Outreach - ensure that all employees understand closure and Privacy principles and apply them correctly in the performance of their duties. • Quality Reviews - determine the level at which IRS employees stand and observe disclosure rules, principles and procedures. • Disclosure Help Desk - respond to IRS employee questions related IRS disclosure and conﬁdentiality statutes. • Training - provide employee training regarding disclosure and non- disclosure of information and Privacy Act responsibilities. (

) Headquarters Disclosure Policy and Program Operations (PPO) staff (under the supervision of the HQ Disclosure Manager) or the Associate Director, closure staff may also participate in Disclosure Program activities. (

) The principal objective of the Disclosure Awareness and Outreach program to ensure, to the extent possible, that all employees know the disclosure statutes and principles and apply this knowledge correctly in the of their duties. (

) A successful disclosure awareness and outreach program is predicated on multiplier effect (awareness being further shared and disseminated by ents). This increases the likelihood of employee compliance with disclosure/ privacy statutes and principles. A high degree of compliance translates into following: a. Taxpayer and employee conﬁdence that conﬁdential information is not being misused. b. Reduced incidences of unauthorized access (UNAX) and disclosures. c. Assurance to Congress that the IRS is providing its employees with the knowledge they need to understand and apply disclosure and privacy rules consistently and correctly. (

) The Disclosure Managers are responsible for helping to identify awareness issues and develop materials for ﬁeld employee’s use and distribution. sure PPO staff will also assist with identifying awareness issues and will with ﬁeld staff to develop materials. These products should be used to delivery of a consistent and accurate message. Copies of various presenta- tions and Disclosure Articles are contained on the Disclosure Share Point as well as the Privacy and Disclosure Virtual Library. Internal Revenue Manual
and Responsibilities of Disclosure Managers 11.3.38

c. Assurance to Congress that the IRS is providing its employees with the knowledge they need to understand and apply disclosure and privacy rules consistently and correctly. The Disclosure Managers are responsible for helping to identify awareness issues and develop materials for ﬁeld employee’s use and distribution. Disclo

sure PPO staff will also assist with identifying awareness issues and will work with ﬁeld staff to develop materials. These products should be used to ensure delivery of a consistent and accurate message. Copies of various presenta
tions and Disclosure Articles are contained on the Disclosure Share Point site as well as the Privacy and Disclosure Virtual Library.
11.3 Disclosure of Official

Note: The Privacy and Disclosure Virtual Library provides a “Book a Disclosure Presentation” button which allows other IRS business units to request a closure Awareness Presentation. The Disclosure Manager may be called upon to coordinate Awareness presentations requested through the “Book Disclosure Presentation” button. (

) The Disclosure Managers are responsible for the following awareness objectives: a. Implement plans to deliver awareness activities on an on-going basis. plans are established by PGLD management and identiﬁed in the GLDS Strategic Plan or in other initiatives. Note: Resources must be made available to provide sufficient coverage those areas required to be addressed as identiﬁed by Director, GLDS or by the Associate Director, Disclosure. b. Document all efforts to promote awareness. Issues covered in efforts should be relevant, timely and accurate. Disclosure Managers will review outlines or notes prepared by the Disclosure employee, for technical accuracy. Disclosure PPO staff, under the direction of the HQ Disclosure Manager, will review any new awareness resources that are not already published or catalogued in the Disclosure Awareness tation Library. (
) HQ Disclosure PPO staff (under the supervision of the HQ Disclosure Manager) or the Associate Director, Disclosure staff will also support awareness activities. (
) Additional information on Disclosure Manager Responsibilities regarding the Awareness and Outreach Program can be found in the Disclosure Manager Expectations document. (
) Quality reviews are used to determine the level at which IRS employees un- derstand and observe disclosure rules, principles and procedures. (

) Quality reviews: a. Allow analysis of the effectiveness of awareness efforts. b. Isolate areas of disclosure weakness. c. Assess progress in overcoming these weaknesses. d. Determine areas where additional emphasis is appropriate. (
) Reviews to be conducted will be determined by PGLD management and ﬁed in the annual GLDS Strategic Plan or other management directives. (

) Quality reviews conducted by the functions are methods of measuring sure compliance. Note: Records management requirements must be considered during reviews, pecially in light of Privacy Act and IRS Privacy Principles standards that generally require only relevant and necessary records be maintained. See IRM
, Records and Information Management for additional information on records management requirements.

PPO. b. Advising PPO Disclosure on any perceived needs for quality reviews based on their observations. c. Sharing the results of the PPO Quality reviews with their employees, ensuring an understanding of the issues and remedies d. Ensuring review results are included in awareness activities with the functions reviewed. The following is a non-exhaustive list of suggested topics that may warrant a quality review. The planning of reviews will occur at the PPO level and be predicated upon the availability of resources to deliver the review. • IRC §
(c) disclosure consents • IRC §
(d) disclosures to State tax agencies • IRC §
(e) material interest • IRC §

) investigative disclosures • IRC §

) Department of Labor and Pension Beneﬁt Guaranty Corporation • Government Accountability Office (GAO) or Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA) Reports on the results of the reviews will be completed by an analyst on the PPO staff and will include the following: a. Subject: Information about what was reviewed. Note: Language similar to the following can be used: “A review of open case ﬁles was conducted on Revenue Agent Groups” b. References: A brief discussion or summary establishing the authority for Disclosure to conduct the review or reference to the applicable IRM provision or program letter that requires these reviews. References to

and the GLDS Program Letter are acceptable. c. Background: A brief discussion about the purpose and intent of the review. Including comments regarding what or who was reviewed and the overall reasons why the review was conducted. Note: Language similar to the following can be used: “A review of Revenue Agent groups was conducted to determine the level of understanding that compliance employees have with disclosure visions. Information gathered from the review will be used to focus future awareness activities and to correct any weaknesses found a result of this review. ” d. Method of Review: A discussion of what was reviewed and how, the scope and sample size of the review, and the methodology for the selection of cases for review. Include in this section of the report informa- tion on how the sample was selected and other important information on the choice of that sample or selected cases for review. e. Findings/Analysis: This should include an in-depth discussion of the results of the review, highlighting both the positives and the negatives of what was noted. Findings must include where improvements are needed or any issues found. Many times, check sheets are available speciﬁc to

d. Method of Review: A discussion of what was reviewed and how, the scope and sample size of the review, and the methodology for the selection of cases for review. Include in this section of the report informa
tion on how the sample was selected and other important information on the choice of that sample or selected cases for review. e. Findings/Analysis: This should include an in

depth discussion of the results of the review, highlighting both the positives and the negatives of what was noted. Findings must include where improvements are needed or any issues found. Many times, check sheets are available speciﬁc to

Disclosure of Official the function or the disclosure issues likely to be encountered. These sheets can be found on the Disclosure Share Point site. Authors have a lot of latitude in how this part of the report is written, but it may be to take each section of the check sheet and write a brief summary of whether or not any issues or ﬁndings were noted. There is no set format as long as adequate details pertaining to the results of the review are listed. f. Recommendations: Actions the function should take to address any ﬁndings noted. For every ﬁnding, there must be a recommendation. The recommendations should be something affirmative that management or IRS employees can control or accomplish with either a change in procedure, increased awareness or some other action. g. Conclusions: A discussion and calculation of the compliance rate (take the number of errorless cases divided by the number of cases reviewed, and convert to a percentage to get the overall compliance rate), whether the overall results were favorable or not, recommendations for any follow-up reviews or awareness activities and when, if known. (

) The HQ Disclosure PPO staff will conduct an analysis of signiﬁcant trends for use in drafting an overall executive summary report discussing results of the review and planned actions to address disclosure issues noted to share with appropriate PGLD management. (
) The Deputy ADs, Disclosure (East and West) are required to provide (managers and staff) to support the Servicewide Disclosure Help Desk. (

) The Help Desk is responsible for responding to IRS employee questions and inquiries related to IRS disclosure and conﬁdentiality statutes and the employees’ responsibilities in adhering to them. Many of the questions received on the Disclosure Help Desk may be answered with resources on Privacy and Disclosure Virtual Library. See IRM
) The Deputy ADs ensure their DMs provide adequate staff coverage of the phone system. (
) DMs also ensure their staff direct calls for Disclosure Office assistance to the Help Desk and encourage all callers to use the system when questions requiring Disclosure expertise arise. (
) The Disclosure Help Desk contact information is found on the Privacy and closure Virtual Library and is for IRS employees only. (
) DMs are responsible for ensuring employees receive training regarding sure and non-disclosure of information and Privacy Act responsibilities. (

) The DMs should use the following guidelines to carry out training ties: a. Provide technical guidance and direction to all employees. b. Ensure the adequacy, quality and effectiveness of disclosure-related training programs by assisting in development of local training materials and attending local training classes to address employees’ concerns and answer disclosure-related questions. ) Disclosure coordinates certain activities with other offices within PGLD, primarily the Office of Governmental Liaison (GL) and the Office of Coordination (

) The GLDS Roles and Responsibilities Matrix, found on the Disclosure Governmental Point site is an important resource in understanding the coordination and Safeguards between Disclosure, GL and Safeguards. (

) The Disclosure Manager, in coordination and collaboration with the GL, has responsibility for: a. Developing basic and implementing agreements and memorandums of understanding and ensuring compliance (e.g. need and use determina- tions) with the basic agreement, all supporting agreements, and all memorandums of understanding. b. Making need and use determinations and conducting an annual need use review with each agency. c. Assisting and responding to inquiries from state taxing authorities for speciﬁc Federal Tax Information. d. Ensuring preparation of disclosure accountings. e. Preparing Disclosure Awareness and other training, including UNAX, to federal, state, and local agency employees. (

) The DM is responsible for ensuring that disclosure standards are in the basic agreement, implementing agreements, or any other type of agreement or memorandum of understanding that may exist between state agencies and the IRS. To carry out this responsibility, DMs must: a. Consult with the GL and state tax agency officials regarding disclosure problems involved in proposed formal agreements on coordination of administration. Review the execution of such agreements as necessary. b. Assist the GL in negotiations with state tax agency officials concerning provisions of agreements that will supplement the basic agreement. The Disclosure Manager, in coordination and collaboration with the GL, has responsibility for: a. Developing basic and implementing agreements and memorandums of understanding and ensuring compliance (e.g. need and use determina- tions) with the basic agreement, all supporting agreements, and all memorandums of understanding. b. Making need and use determinations and conducting an annual need use review with each agency. c. Assisting and responding to inquiries from state taxing authorities for speciﬁc Federal Tax Information. d. Ensuring preparation of disclosure accountings. e. Preparing Disclosure Awareness and other training, including UNAX, to federal, state, and local agency employees. Consult with the GL and state tax agency officials regarding disclosure problems involved in proposed formal agreements on coordination of tax administration. Review the execution of such agreements as necessary. b. Assist the GL in negotiations with state tax agency officials concerning provisions of agreements that will supplement the basic agreement. ) DMs are expected to advise the GLs on disclosure provisions. (

) All exchanges of tax information fall into one of the following categories: a. Implementing agreements or memorandums of understanding or b. Speciﬁc requests (made outside of the Implementing Agreement or randum of Understanding) or c. Electronic data exchanges (that can be referenced in Implementing ments or Memorandums of Understanding or speciﬁc requests). Note: Additional information on the Secure Data Transfer (SDT) data exchanges can be found on the Disclosure Share Point site. (

) DMs and staff also support efforts by GLs in exploring opportunities for exchange of tax information with other federal agencies and provide advice related to various disclosure provisions related to these exchanges. (

) The purpose of the Safeguard review program is to ensure: a. Disclosure of tax returns and tax return information by the IRS to external agencies, their authorized agents, and their authorized contractors is in accordance with statutory authority. b. Tax information is used by these recipients only as authorized by the enabling legislation and/or implementing regulations.

) DMs and Disclosure staff assist the Office of Safeguards, and any other IRS personnel with issues related to the interpretation and application of IRC and the Privacy Act as they relate to information shared with or disclosed by the various Federal, State and Local agencies and contractors. (

) IRS employees are required to report suspected willful unauthorized inspections/disclosures of returns and return information and Privacy Act tions to the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA). Field employees should report these matters to the local TIGTA Special Agent. Washington, DC metro area employees should report to TIGTA’s main office. TIGTA Office Locations can be found at the TIGTA website. (

) Non-willful unauthorized disclosures of tax or Privacy Act protected are to be reported in accordance with the reporting procedures found on the Privacy and Disclosure Virtual Library web page. See IRM
, Reporting Non-willful Inadvertent Disclosures below for additional information. Note: A willful act is one where there is an intentional violation of a known legal

Note: If any employee reports an unauthorized willful disclosure/inspection to a Disclosure Manager before reporting it to TIGTA, the Disclosure Manager will direct the employee to TIGTA without delay.

) The Deputy ADs, Disclosure East and Disclosure West, serve as the for the ﬁeld DMs under their areas of responsibility and report to the Director, Disclosure. (

) The Deputy AD: • Manages the Disclosure program in his/her area • Assists the Director, GLDS, and Associate Director, Disclosure in menting the national disclosure program • Ensures Disclosure employees receive training regarding disclosure information requirements (

) To be effective, the Deputy AD should: a. Provide necessary managerial assistance and support to DMs and staff. b. Assess the effectiveness of the Disclosure programs through visitations and reviews. c. Prepare procedures and instructions for local offices concerning programs. d. Support the importance of privacy as well as the importance of the sure program. Understand and embrace the role the local Disclosure plays in protecting the conﬁdentiality of tax information and sensitive tax information. e. Monitor disclosure office compliance with Headquarters’ directives and guidelines and ensure that GLDS priorities are followed. f. Conduct reviews of Disclosure casework to determine if appropriate standards are being met, and procedures are being followed. g. Review and approve exchange agreements for conformity with IRC §

(d) and the Privacy Act. h. Determine which technical issues require Headquarters’ action; suggest new legislation, regulations and procedures to Headquarters as i. Advise Headquarters of procedural problems which may extend beyond Area jurisdiction, detail efforts made to resolve them, and offer sugges- tions to prevent recurrence. j. Provide input as required by Headquarters on the status of Disclosure tivities within the Area. k. Coordinate, consolidate, and ensure that required reports are complete, timely, and accurate.

) In addition to program and case management responsibilities, DMs also have supervisory (i.e., front line management) responsibilities for technical and clerical personnel. As such, they must perform the full range of tasks expected of all IRS supervisors. (

) The supervisory responsibilities of the DM will include: a. Ensure employee case actions are timely and in accordance with current law, policies, and procedures; b. Ensure employees maintain high standards of professionalism in all their contacts with the public, internal customers and coworkers; c. Ensure employees observe taxpayer rights; d. Ensure employees are aware of ongoing changes to the laws, policies, and procedures that relate to their responsibilities (preferably during group meetings); e. Address systems issues that impact either internal or external customer needs; f. Ensure cases are assigned timely and employee workload do the following:

Ensure employees are accountable for the appropriateness of their actions; Provide ongoing employee feedback that is candid and meaningful and will establish a basis for determining an accurate assessment of perfor

mance and developmental needs; Issue the Critical Job Elements (CJE) timely in accordance with the current National Agreement and evaluating employees performance against their CJEs; Create and maintain a work environment that will promote team work, positive working relationships, and increased employee satisfaction; Ensure employees have necessary functioning equipment and supplies. Supervisory Responsibilities of the Disclosure Manager are the Disclosure Manager Expectations document found on the Disclosure

) IRM
, Management Roles and Responsibilities, describes the responsibilities of management positions at all levels and should be for additional information. (

) Disclosure uses an electronic inventory management system for input, processing, and closing assigned case and program work. This is a helpful Inventory for DMs to monitor all activities of their office. It is important that the data entries made are accurate and timely. DMs must include comments in case reviews or in other observations about the accuracy and completeness of required data entry and case history notes. (
) GLDS Data Services is responsible for the operations of the system and should be contacted in the event of any connectivity or functionality issues. (
) DMs are to use the reports generated by the system as a tool to assist in tifying trends, addressing inventory management issues and in reporting accomplishments to the Deputy AD. (
) The speciﬁc duties of Disclosure Specialists are determined by their descriptions. The assignments are technical and non-supervisory in nature. the (
) Specialists generally handle day-to-day technical issues (i.e., casework). Specialist (
) Disclosure Specialists with sufficient experience may be assigned for aspects of program management as needed and act for the DM in his or her absence. (
) Disclosure Specialists may be asked to coordinate or conduct awareness sentations, or complete Quality reviews. (

) Senior Disclosure Specialists may have additional assignments or ties based on their position descriptions. Senior Disclosure Specialists may also be assigned responsibility for aspects of program management, guidance to lower graded specialists and act for the DM in his or her (
) Effective January

, the job series of the Disclosure Specialist and Senior Disclosure Specialist was changed to Government Information ist; however the working title of the employee remained as Disclosure Specialist or Senior Disclosure Specialist. (
) The Disclosure Assistant performs a variety of duties in assisting in the istration of local disclosure policies, practices and procedures. the (
) These duties normally include processing the more routine type of FOIA, Assistant Privacy Act and IRC §
requests, as well as performing many of the ad- ministrative duties, such as preparing accountings for disclosure and certiﬁcation of documents. (

) The speciﬁc duties of the Tax Law Specialist are determined by their descriptions. The assignments for a Tax Law Specialist may be more the Tax Law or sensitive than assignments of other Disclosure employees. (
) Tax Law Specialists may also be assigned responsibility for aspects of program management and act for the DM in his or her absence. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
